Homogenization of a class of one-dimensional nonconvex viscous Hamilton-Jacobi equations with random potential

(Date: October 8, 2017.)
Abstract.

We prove the homogenization of a class of one-dimensional viscous Hamilton-Jacobi equations with random Hamiltonians that are nonconvex in the gradient variable. Due to the special form of the Hamiltonians, the solutions of these PDEs with linear initial conditions have representations involving exponential expectations of controlled Brownian motion in a random potential. The effective Hamiltonian is the asymptotic rate of growth of these exponential expectations as time goes to infinity and is explicit in terms of the tilted free energy of (uncontrolled) Brownian motion in a random potential. The proof involves large deviations, construction of correctors which lead to exponential martingales, and identification of asymptotically optimal policies.

Key words and phrases:
Hamilton-Jacobi, homogenization, correctors, Brownian motion in a random potential, large deviations, tilted free energy, risk-sensitive stochastic optimal control, asymptotically optimal policy, bang-bang.
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
35B27, 60K37, 93E20.

A. Yilmaz was partially supported by the BAGEP Award of the Science Academy, Turkey.

Thus, we obtain a full homogenization result for a new class of viscous Hamilton-Jacobi equations with nonconvex (when c>0𝑐0c>0) Hamiltonians in dimension 1.

The solution of (1.1)-(1.2) rewritten as a terminal value problem is also known to characterize the value of a two-player, zero-sum stochastic differential game (see, for instance, [FS89]). But due to the special form of (1.1), our homogenization problem admits a simple and useful control interpretation, where, roughly speaking, the role of one of the players is implicitly assumed by the diffusion in the random environment. More precisely, let (Xt)t≥0subscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑡0(X_{t})_{t\geq 0} be a standard Brownian motion (BM) that is independent of the environment. We denote by (𝒢t)t≥0subscriptsubscript𝒢𝑡𝑡0(\mathcal{G}_{t})_{t\geq 0} the natural filtration and by P0subscript𝑃0P_{0} (resp. E0subscript𝐸0E_{0}) the probability (resp. expectation) corresponding to this BM when X0=0subscript𝑋00X_{0}=0. and the initial condition vθ​(0,x,ω)=eθ​xsubscript𝑣𝜃0𝑥𝜔superscript𝑒𝜃𝑥v_{\theta}(0,x,\omega)=e^{\theta x}. where

is the set of admissible controls, and (Xsα)s≥0subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑋𝛼𝑠𝑠0(X^{\alpha}_{s})_{s\geq 0} is defined by

The control interpretation (1.7) indicates that, contrary to the case c=0𝑐0c=0 for which the existence of the limit can be easily shown by subadditivity arguments, allowing c>0𝑐0c>0 destroys subadditivity. Hence, even the existence of the limit in (1.7) becomes a nontrivial statement. We are able not only to show that the limit in (1.7) exists and get a semi-explicit expression for it but also to provide asymptotically optimal controls (see Section 4.3).

Recall that the original Hamiltonian Hβ,c​(p,ω)subscript𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑝𝜔H_{\beta,c}(p,\omega) is nonconvex in p𝑝p for all β,c>0𝛽𝑐0\beta,c>0. We show that in our setting the convexity/nonconvexity of the effective Hamiltonian depends only on the magnitude of the potential and the size of the control. More precisely, H¯β,csubscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐\overline{H}_{\beta,c} is convex if and only if β≥c2/2𝛽superscript𝑐22\beta\geq c^{2}/2 (see Figure 1). The “convexification” of the effective Hamiltonian has been previously observed for the first order Hamilton-Jacobi equations in [ATY15], [ATY16], [QTY17].

1.2. Broader context

We shall refer to the equation of the form

(1.9) ∂uε∂t=ε2​tr ​(A​(Tx/ε​ω)​D2​uε)+H​(D​uε,Tx/ε​ω),(t,x)∈(0,∞)×ℝd,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑢𝜀𝑡𝜀2tr 𝐴subscript𝑇𝑥𝜀𝜔superscript𝐷2superscript𝑢𝜀𝐻𝐷superscript𝑢𝜀subscript𝑇𝑥𝜀𝜔𝑡𝑥0superscriptℝ𝑑\frac{\partial u^{\varepsilon}}{\partial t}=\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\text{tr\,}(A(T_{x/\varepsilon}\omega)D^{2}u^{\varepsilon})+H(Du^{\varepsilon},T_{x/\varepsilon}\omega),\quad(t,x)\in(0,\infty)\times\mathbb{R}^{d},

as a viscous Hamilton-Jacobi equation if the symmetric positive semi-definite matrix A≢0not-equivalent-to𝐴0A\not\equiv 0 and as an inviscid Hamilton-Jacobi equation (or simply Hamilton-Jacobi equation) if A≡0𝐴0A\equiv 0.

By change of variables we can always write uε​(t,x,ω)=ε​u​(t/ε,x/ε,ω)superscript𝑢𝜀𝑡𝑥𝜔𝜀𝑢𝑡𝜀𝑥𝜀𝜔u^{\varepsilon}(t,x,\omega)=\varepsilon u(t/\varepsilon,x/\varepsilon,\omega) where u​(t,x,ω)𝑢𝑡𝑥𝜔u(t,x,\omega) solves (1.9) for ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1. Thus, we are interested in the existence of a scaling limit under the hyperbolic scaling of time and space. Note that linear initial conditions are invariant under this scaling. We shall say that (1.9) with initial condition g​(x)𝑔𝑥g(x) homogenizes if with probability one uε​(t,x,ω)superscript𝑢𝜀𝑡𝑥𝜔u^{\varepsilon}(t,x,\omega) converges locally uniformly in t𝑡t and x𝑥x to the solution u¯​(t,x)¯𝑢𝑡𝑥\overline{u}(t,x) of a deterministic PDE with the same initial condition. If the convergence is only in probability then we shall say that the problem homogenizes in probability.

It has been shown that if the Hamiltonian H​(p,ω)𝐻𝑝𝜔H(p,\omega) is convex in the momentum variables (p∈ℝd𝑝superscriptℝ𝑑p\in\mathbb{R}^{d}), then homogenization holds for very general viscous and inviscid Hamilton-Jacobi equations in all dimensions. The literature on the subject is vast. We shall focus primarily on the viscous case and refer the reader to [LS05], [KRV06], [AS12], [AT14], [AC15a], and the references therein.

If the Hamiltonian H​(p,x)𝐻𝑝𝑥H(p,x) is 1-periodic in each of the spatial variables, then there is a general method of proving homogenization due to [LPV87] (see [Eva92] for an extension to general first and second order fully nonlinear PDEs). The method is based on the construction of correctors. Correctors are sublinear (at infinity) solutions to a certain family of nonlinear eigenvalue problems, see (2.11) for our case. The applicability of the method does not depend on the convexity of the Hamiltonian but rather on the coercivity of the Hamiltonian in p𝑝p and the compactness of the space (x𝑥x changes on a torus). The method of correctors originated in the study of linear partial differential equations with periodic coefficients, and we refer the interested reader to the monographs [BLP78], [JKO94].

In the more general stochastic setting, [RT00, Theorem 4.1] asserted that if sublinear correctors exist for each vector in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} then the (inviscid) stochastic problem homogenizes. However, soon it was shown ([LS03]) that in the stochastic case correctors need not exist in general. Thus, other methods were developed. One of them was introduced already in [LPV87] as an alternative method for the (inviscid) periodic problem with a convex Hamiltonian. Convexity played an important role. First of all, it allowed one to use the control representation of solutions. Furthermore, the convexity assumption implied the subadditivity of certain solution-defining quantities, and the homogenization result could be obtained from a subadditive ergodic theorem.

The first two papers which addressed the stochastic homogenization of viscous Hamilton-Jacobi equations, [LS05] and [KRV06], used variational representations of the solutions. In an attempt to steer away from representation formulas and following some ideas in [Szn94] and [LS10], the paper [AS12] introduced a method based on the so-called metric problem. The convexity assumption gives a subadditivity property to solutions of the metric problem and, thus, still essentially restricts the approach to convex Hamiltonians (level-set convex in the inviscid case, [AS13]). This approach was further developed in [AT14] and [AC15a] where some assumptions are relaxed and a rate of convergence is obtained.

For quite some time it was not clear whether the convexity assumption can be disposed of in the stochastic setting. Several classes of examples of nonconvex Hamiltonians for which homogenization holds were recently constructed: [ATY15], [ATY16], [Gao16], [FS16], [QTY17] for inviscid equations and [AC15b], [DK17] for viscous equations. On the other hand, the work [Zil15] has demonstrated that homogenization could fail for nonconvex Hamiltonians in the general stationary and ergodic setting for dimensions d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2. (See also [FS16].) These results indicate that the homogenization or non-homogenization for nonconvex Hamiltonians depends significantly on the interplay between the nonconvexity and the random environment, and that one cannot expect a comprehensive solution. The case of viscous equations is particularly difficult, since the viscosity term adds yet another randomness, encoded in the diffusion. The critical scaling at which the diffusion enters the equation brings into play the large deviations for this diffusion and makes the analysis even more challenging.

In spite of the negative results of [LS03] on the existence of correctors for (1.9), the quest for them has never ended (see, for example, [DS09], [DS12], [AC15b]). In particular, the authors of [CS17] have shown under quite general conditions that if the equation (1.9) homogenizes in probability to an effective equation with some continuous and coercive Hamiltonian H¯​(p)¯𝐻𝑝\overline{H}(p) then correctors exist for every p𝑝p that is an extreme point of the convex hull of the sub-level set {q∈ℝd:H¯​(q)≤H¯​(p)}conditional-set𝑞superscriptℝ𝑑¯𝐻𝑞¯𝐻𝑝\{q\in\mathbb{R}^{d}:\,\overline{H}(q)\leq\overline{H}(p)\}. In discrete multidimensional settings such as first passage percolation, random walks in random environments and directed polymers, the existence of correctors (and closely related Busemann functions) also received a lot of attention (see, e.g., [Yil11], [DH14], [Kri16], [GRAS16], [BL16]).

1.3. Motivation, method and outline

Given the above developments and the complexity of the general homogenization problem with a nonconvex Hamiltonian, one can start with a more modest goal and look first at some model examples of viscous Hamilton-Jacobi equations in dimension 1. For the inviscid case in dimension 1 there are already quite general homogenization results, see [ATY15] and [Gao16]. It is natural to conjecture that homogenization in dimension 1 holds under general assumptions in the viscous case as well. Methods which were used in the inviscid case are not applicable to the viscous case due to the presence of the diffusion term.

In this paper we provide a new class of examples in the viscous one-dimensional case for which homogenization holds. Our examples, in a way, complement some of those considered earlier in [DK17, Theorem 4.10]. More precisely, the method of [DK17] is applicable to Hamiltonians which have one or more “pinning points” (i.e. values p∗superscript𝑝p^{*} such that H​(p∗,⋅)≡const𝐻superscript𝑝⋅constH(p^{*},\cdot)\equiv\text{const}) and are convex in p𝑝p in between the pinning points. For example, H​(p,ω)=12​p2−b​(ω)​|p|𝐻𝑝𝜔12superscript𝑝2𝑏𝜔𝑝H(p,\omega)=\frac{1}{2}\,p^{2}-b(\omega)|p|, b​(ω)>0𝑏𝜔0b(\omega)>0, is pinned at p∗=0superscript𝑝0p^{*}=0 and is convex in p𝑝p on (−∞,0)0(-\infty,0) and (0,∞)0(0,\infty). Adding a non-constant potential breaks the pinning property. Currently it is not known if (1.9) with

(1.10) H​(p,ω)=12​|p|2−b​(ω)​|p|+β​V​(ω)𝐻𝑝𝜔12superscript𝑝2𝑏𝜔𝑝𝛽𝑉𝜔H(p,\omega)=\frac{1}{2}\,|p|^{2}-b(\omega)|p|+\beta V(\omega)

and A≡const≢0𝐴constnot-equivalent-to0A\equiv\text{const}\not\equiv 0 homogenizes even in dimension 1. Our results give a positive answer in the case when b​(ω)≡c>0𝑏𝜔𝑐0b(\omega)\equiv c>0 and V𝑉V satisfies (1.3)-(1.5).

To prove Theorem 1.2 we first consider the convex case c=0𝑐0c=0 (no-control case for (1.7)) and construct a function Fβ,θsubscript𝐹𝛽𝜃F_{\beta,\theta} for every θ𝜃\theta outside of the closed interval where the tilted free energy Λβ​(θ)subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta) (see (2.1)) attains its minimum value β𝛽\beta, i.e. outside of the so-called “flat piece” of the effective Hamiltonian H¯β,0≡Λβsubscript¯𝐻𝛽0subscriptΛ𝛽\overline{H}_{\beta,0}\equiv\Lambda_{\beta}. The function Fβ,θsubscript𝐹𝛽𝜃F_{\beta,\theta} is used to introduce the exponential martingale Mt​(ω)subscript𝑀𝑡𝜔M_{t}(\omega), see (2.12); for this reason we call Fβ,θsubscript𝐹𝛽𝜃F_{\beta,\theta} a corrector. The martingale Mt​(ω)subscript𝑀𝑡𝜔M_{t}(\omega) immediately yields the desired limit. For each c>0𝑐0c>0 we build the effective Hamiltonian H¯β,csubscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐\overline{H}_{\beta,c} by shifting and bridging together pieces of Λβ(⋅±c)\Lambda_{\beta}(\cdot\pm c) (see Section 4.3 and Figure 1). We note that in our setting correctors exist for all θ𝜃\theta outside of the “flat pieces” of H¯β,c​(θ)subscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝜃\overline{H}_{\beta,c}(\theta) and coincide with those constructed in the no-control case for an appropriately shifted θ𝜃\theta. We use each of these correctors to define an exponential expression (see (4.4)) which turns out to be (i) a submartingale for arbitrary control policies and (ii) a martingale for specific control policies that we deduce to be asymptotically optimal.

The above approach was first proposed and implemented in [YZ17] in the discrete setting where the BM in the control problem (1.7) is replaced by a random walk, the analog of Theorem 1.2 is proved for a viscous Hamilton-Jacobi partial difference equation and the effective Hamiltonian is shown to have the same structure as in this paper. However, as it is often the case, the arguments in the continuous formulation differ noticeably. We believe that some of the ideas in [YZ17] and this paper can be extended to more general settings, for example, to Hamiltonians of the form (1.10) in one or more dimensions.

We end this introduction with a brief outline of the rest of the paper. Section 2 focuses on the no-control case. We obtain a uniform lower bound using the existence of arbitrarily long high hills, construct the aforementioned correctors, use them to give a self-contained proof of the existence of the tilted free energy (Theorem 2.9) and list some of the properties of the latter (Proposition 2.10). Section 3 contains upper bounds for the control problem. We restrict the infimum in (1.7) to bang-bang policies, consider the constant policies α←≡−c←𝛼𝑐\overleftarrow{\alpha}\equiv-c and α→≡c→𝛼𝑐\overrightarrow{\alpha}\equiv c as well as a family of policies α(x∗,h,y)superscript𝛼subscript𝑥ℎ𝑦\alpha^{(x_{*},h,y)} which tries to trap the particle to low valleys. These upper bounds produce the graphs in Figure 1. Section 4 provides matching lower bounds. We obtain a uniform lower bound similar to that in the no-control case, use the correctors outside of the flat pieces as mentioned above, give a scaling argument at the elevated flat piece centered at the origin when β<c2/2𝛽superscript𝑐22\beta<c^{2}/2, and thereby prove the existence of the effective Hamiltonian (Theorem 4.3). Finally, Section 5 wraps up the solution of the homogenization problem. We derive the control representation and put our limit results (Theorems 2.9 and 4.3) together with relevant results from [DK17] to prove Theorem 1.2 and Corollary 1.4. Note that the regularity assumption (1.4) on V𝑉V is used only in Section 5 and it is replaced by the weaker continuity assumption (2.2) in Sections 2, 3 and 4.

Introducing these correctors is in fact our main motivation here since they will play a key role in our solution of the control problem (i.e. showing the existence of the limit on the RHS of (1.7) for c>0𝑐0c>0) in Section 4.

Lemma 2.6.

If β<ΛβU​(θ)𝛽superscriptsubscriptΛ𝛽𝑈𝜃\beta<\Lambda_{\beta}^{U}(\theta), then there exists a λo=λo​(β,θ)≥ΛβU​(θ)subscript𝜆𝑜subscript𝜆𝑜𝛽𝜃superscriptsubscriptΛ𝛽𝑈𝜃\lambda_{o}=\lambda_{o}(\beta,\theta)\geq\Lambda_{\beta}^{U}(\theta) such that 𝔼​[Fβ,θλo​(⋅,1)]=0𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐹𝛽𝜃subscript𝜆𝑜⋅10\mathbb{E}[F_{\beta,\theta}^{\lambda_{o}}(\cdot,1)]=0.

Assume that θ>0𝜃0\theta>0. The map λ↦𝔼​[Fβ,θλ​(⋅,1)]maps-to𝜆𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐹𝛽𝜃𝜆⋅1\lambda\mapsto\mathbb{E}[F_{\beta,\theta}^{\lambda}(\cdot,1)] is continuous and strictly increasing for λ≥β𝜆𝛽\lambda\geq\beta. Moreover,

limλ→∞𝔼​[Fβ,θλ​(⋅,1)]=∞.subscript→𝜆𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐹𝛽𝜃𝜆⋅1\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mathbb{E}\left[F_{\beta,\theta}^{\lambda}(\cdot,1)\right]=\infty.

These assertions follow from the P0subscript𝑃0P_{0}-a.s. positivity of τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}, the uniform (in ω𝜔\omega) bounds in (2.5) and the dominated convergence theorem. Recalling Lemma 2.5, we deduce the desired result. The θ<0𝜃0\theta<0 case is similar. ∎

In the rest of this paper, we write Fβ,θ​(ω,x)=Fβ,θλo​(ω,x)subscript𝐹𝛽𝜃𝜔𝑥superscriptsubscript𝐹𝛽𝜃subscript𝜆𝑜𝜔𝑥F_{\beta,\theta}(\omega,x)=F_{\beta,\theta}^{\lambda_{o}}(\omega,x) for notational brevity. The following proposition (whose proof is deferred to Appendix A) lists some properties of the tilted free energy.

Proposition 2.10.

Assume that V𝑉V satisfies the conditions in Theorem 2.9. Then, the following properties are true.

  • (a)

    Λβ​(θ)subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta) is increasing in β𝛽\beta, and even and convex in θ𝜃\theta.

  • (b)

    max⁡{β,θ2/2}≤Λβ​(θ)≤β+θ2/2𝛽superscript𝜃22subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝛽superscript𝜃22\max\left\{\beta,\theta^{2}/2\right\}\leq\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta)\leq\beta+\theta^{2}/2.

  • (c)

    {θ∈ℝ:Λβ​(θ)=β}conditional-set𝜃ℝsubscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝛽\{\theta\in\mathbb{R}:\,\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta)=\beta\} is a symmetric and closed interval with nonempty interior.

  • (d)

    The function θ↦Λβ​(θ)maps-to𝜃subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃\theta\mapsto\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta) is C1superscript𝐶1C^{1} on the complement of {θ∈ℝ:Λβ​(θ)=β}conditional-set𝜃ℝsubscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝛽\{\theta\in\mathbb{R}:\,\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta)=\beta\}.

Proposition 2.10(d) is included here as an application of the implicit formula we provide for Λβ​(θ)subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta) in Theorem 2.9, and it is not used anywhere in the paper. Note that this proposition does not answer the question of whether the function θ↦Λβ​(θ)maps-to𝜃subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃\theta\mapsto\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta) is differentiable at the endpoints of the interval {θ∈ℝ:Λβ​(θ)=β}conditional-set𝜃ℝsubscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝛽\{\theta\in\mathbb{R}:\,\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta)=\beta\}. A negative answer to this question is given in [YZ17, Appendix D] in the discrete setting.

3. Upper bounds

Our next goal is to prove that the limit

and

In this section, we give upper bounds for H¯β,cU​(θ)superscriptsubscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑈𝜃\overline{H}_{\beta,c}^{U}(\theta) by considering specific (families of) policies. We assume throughout these two sections that V𝑉V satisfies (1.3), (1.5) and (2.2).

3.1. Bang-bang policies

For every c>0𝑐0c>0, let

Substituting the bang-bang policies α←≡−c←𝛼𝑐\overleftarrow{\alpha}\equiv-c and α→≡c→𝛼𝑐\overrightarrow{\alpha}\equiv c into the RHS of (3.3), we readily get the following bound:

4. Lower bounds and the effective Hamiltonian

In this section, we continue assuming that c>0𝑐0c>0 and V𝑉V satisfies (1.3), (1.5) and (2.2).

4.1. Uniform lower bound

For every α∈𝒫c𝛼subscript𝒫𝑐\alpha\in\mathcal{P}_{c},

It remains to consider the cases not covered by Lemma 4.2. If θ=0𝜃0\theta=0, then (since V​(⋅)≥0𝑉⋅0V(\cdot)\geq 0) it is clear from (3.2) that

4.3. The effective Hamiltonian

We are ready to check that the lower bounds we have obtained in this section match the upper bounds from Section 3.

Theorem 4.3.

Assume that V𝑉V satisfies (1.3), (1.5) and (2.2). Then, the limit in (3.1) exists for every β>0𝛽0\beta>0, c>0𝑐0c>0, θ∈ℝ𝜃ℝ\theta\in\mathbb{R} and ℙℙ\mathbb{P}-a.e. ω𝜔\omega. Moreover, there are two qualitatively distinct control regimes which are characterized by the comparison of β𝛽\beta and c2/2superscript𝑐22c^{2}/2 (see Figure 1).

  • (a)

    (Weak control) If β≥c2/2𝛽superscript𝑐22\beta\geq c^{2}/2, then the effective Hamiltonian is given by

    (4.7) H¯β,c​(θ)={β−12​c2if​|θ|<c,Λβ​(|θ|−c)−12​c2if​|θ|≥c.subscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝜃cases𝛽12superscript𝑐2if𝜃𝑐subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝑐12superscript𝑐2if𝜃𝑐\overline{H}_{\beta,c}(\theta)=\begin{cases}\beta-\frac{1}{2}c^{2}&\ \text{if}\ |\theta|<c,\\ \Lambda_{\beta}(|\theta|-c)-\frac{1}{2}c^{2}&\ \text{if}\ |\theta|\geq c.\end{cases}
  • (b)

    (Strong control) If β<c2/2𝛽superscript𝑐22\beta<c^{2}/2, then there exists a unique θ¯​(β,c)∈(0,c)¯𝜃𝛽𝑐0𝑐\bar{\theta}(\beta,c)\in(0,c) such that

    Λβ​(θ¯​(β,c)−c)=12​c2,subscriptΛ𝛽¯𝜃𝛽𝑐𝑐12superscript𝑐2\Lambda_{\beta}(\bar{\theta}(\beta,c)-c)=\frac{1}{2}c^{2},

    and the effective Hamiltonian is given by

    (4.8) H¯β,c​(θ)={0if​|θ|<|θ¯​(β,c)|,Λβ​(|θ|−c)−12​c2if​|θ|≥|θ¯​(β,c)|.subscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝜃cases0if𝜃¯𝜃𝛽𝑐subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝑐12superscript𝑐2if𝜃¯𝜃𝛽𝑐\overline{H}_{\beta,c}(\theta)=\begin{cases}0&\ \text{if}\ |\theta|<|\bar{\theta}(\beta,c)|,\\ \Lambda_{\beta}(|\theta|-c)-\frac{1}{2}c^{2}&\ \text{if}\ |\theta|\geq|\bar{\theta}(\beta,c)|.\end{cases}
Proof.

We prove the existence of the limit in (3.1) separately in each of the two control regimes.

(a) (Weak control) Assume that β≥c2/2𝛽superscript𝑐22\beta\geq c^{2}/2. By symmetry, it suffices to consider θ≥0𝜃0\theta\geq 0.

  • •

    If 0≤θ≤c0𝜃𝑐0\leq\theta\leq c, then the bounds (3.7) and (4.2) match,

    H¯β,cL​(θ)=H¯β,cU​(θ)=β−12​c2,superscriptsubscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝐿𝜃superscriptsubscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑈𝜃𝛽12superscript𝑐2\overline{H}_{\beta,c}^{L}(\theta)=\overline{H}_{\beta,c}^{U}(\theta)=\beta-\frac{1}{2}c^{2},

    and taking the infimum in (3.1) over the set {α(x∗,h,y): 0<h<h0,y>y0}conditional-setsuperscript𝛼subscript𝑥ℎ𝑦formulae-sequence 0ℎsubscriptℎ0𝑦subscript𝑦0\{\alpha^{(x_{*},h,y)}:\,0<h<h_{0},\ y>y_{0}\} for any h0>0subscriptℎ00h_{0}>0 and y0>0subscript𝑦00y_{0}>0 does not change the limit.

    If θ≥0𝜃0\theta\geq 0 and Λβ​(θ−c)=βsubscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝑐𝛽\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta-c)=\beta, then the bounds (3.4) and (4.2) match,

    H¯β,cL​(θ)=H¯β,cU​(θ)=β−12​c2,superscriptsubscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝐿𝜃superscriptsubscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑈𝜃𝛽12superscript𝑐2\overline{H}_{\beta,c}^{L}(\theta)=\overline{H}_{\beta,c}^{U}(\theta)=\beta-\frac{1}{2}c^{2},

5. Homogenization

In this section, we first state (and give references to) existence and uniqueness results for viscosity solutions to the Cauchy problems we have introduced in Section 1.1, then provide the control representation (5.5)-(5.6) for vθsubscript𝑣𝜃v_{\theta} that we have mentioned there, and finally use (5.6) to prove our homogenization results (Theorem 1.2 and Corollary 1.4). We assume throughout the section that V𝑉V satisfies (1.3), (1.4) and (1.5). Since we work directly with the control representation rather than the equations themselves, we omit the definition of a viscosity solution and refer the reader to [CIL92, FS06].

5.1. Existence and uniqueness

The following results are well known in very general settings (see, for instance, [CIL92, CL86]). We state them here exactly in the form we need and give precise references for the convenience of the reader.

Lemma 5.1.

For every g∈UC​(ℝ)𝑔UCℝg\in\text{UC}(\mathbb{R}), ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and ω∈Ω𝜔Ω\omega\in\Omega, the viscous Hamilton-Jacobi equation (1.1) subject to the initial condition g𝑔g has a unique viscosity solution ugεsubscriptsuperscript𝑢𝜀𝑔u^{\varepsilon}_{g} in UC​([0,∞)×ℝ)UC0ℝ\text{UC}([0,\infty)\times\mathbb{R}).

Proof.

For every ω∈Ω𝜔Ω\omega\in\Omega, the Hamiltonian Hβ,c​(p,Tx​ω)=12​p2−c​|p|+β​V​(Tx​ω)subscript𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑝subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔12superscript𝑝2𝑐𝑝𝛽𝑉subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔H_{\beta,c}(p,T_{x}\omega)=\frac{1}{2}p^{2}-c|p|+\beta V(T_{x}\omega) has the following three properties. First,

(5.1) 14​p2−c2≤12​p2−c​|p|≤Hβ,c​(p,Tx​ω)≤12​p2+β14superscript𝑝2superscript𝑐212superscript𝑝2𝑐𝑝subscript𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑝subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔12superscript𝑝2𝛽\frac{1}{4}p^{2}-c^{2}\leq\frac{1}{2}p^{2}-c|p|\leq H_{\beta,c}(p,T_{x}\omega)\leq\frac{1}{2}p^{2}+\beta

for every (p,x)∈ℝ×ℝ𝑝𝑥ℝℝ(p,x)\in\mathbb{R}\times\mathbb{R} since 0≤(12​|p|−c)2=14​p2+c2−c​|p|0superscript12𝑝𝑐214superscript𝑝2superscript𝑐2𝑐𝑝0\leq(\frac{1}{2}|p|-c)^{2}=\frac{1}{4}p^{2}+c^{2}-c|p| and V​(Tx​ω)∈[0,1]𝑉subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔01V(T_{x}\omega)\in[0,1] by 1.3. Second,

(5.2) x↦Hβ,c​(p,Tx​ω)maps-to𝑥subscript𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑝subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔x\mapsto H_{\beta,c}(p,T_{x}\omega) is Lipschitz continuous

by (1.4). Third,

(5.3) |Hβ,c​(p,Tx​ω)−Hβ,c​(q,Tx​ω)|=|12​(|p|+|q|)−c|​||p|−|q||≤(12​(|p|+|q|)+c)​|p−q|subscript𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑝subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔subscript𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑞subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔12𝑝𝑞𝑐𝑝𝑞12𝑝𝑞𝑐𝑝𝑞|H_{\beta,c}(p,T_{x}\omega)-H_{\beta,c}(q,T_{x}\omega)|=\left|\frac{1}{2}(|p|+|q|)-c\right|||p|-|q||\leq\left(\frac{1}{2}(|p|+|q|)+c\right)|p-q|

for every p,q∈ℝ𝑝𝑞ℝp,q\in\mathbb{R}. The desired result follows from [DK17, Theorem 2.8]. ∎

Lemma 5.2.

For every g∈UC​(ℝ)𝑔UCℝg\in\text{UC}(\mathbb{R}), the inviscid Hamilton-Jacobi equation (1.6) subject to the initial condition g𝑔g has a unique viscosity solution u¯gsubscript¯𝑢𝑔\overline{u}_{g} in UC​([0,∞)×ℝ)UC0ℝ\text{UC}([0,\infty)\times\mathbb{R}).

Proof.

It is clear from (4.7)-(4.8) that the Hamiltonian H¯β,c​(p)subscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑝\overline{H}_{\beta,c}(p) is locally uniformly continuous in p𝑝p. Moreover,

14​p2−c2≤12​p2−c​|p|≤H¯β,c​(p)≤Λβ​(p)≤12​p2+β14superscript𝑝2superscript𝑐212superscript𝑝2𝑐𝑝subscript¯𝐻𝛽𝑐𝑝subscriptΛ𝛽𝑝12superscript𝑝2𝛽\frac{1}{4}p^{2}-c^{2}\leq\frac{1}{2}p^{2}-c|p|\leq\overline{H}_{\beta,c}(p)\leq\Lambda_{\beta}(p)\leq\frac{1}{2}p^{2}+\beta

for every p∈ℝ𝑝ℝp\in\mathbb{R}. Here, the first inequality is as in (5.1), the second inequality is easy to check by taking β=0𝛽0\beta=0 (see also Figure 1), the third inequality holds since α≡0∈𝒫c𝛼0subscript𝒫𝑐\alpha\equiv 0\in\mathcal{P}_{c}, and the last inequality is part of Proposition 2.10(b). The desired result follows from [DK17, Theorem 2.5]. ∎

5.2. Control representation

For every θ∈ℝ𝜃ℝ\theta\in\mathbb{R}, ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, (t,x)∈[0,∞)×ℝ𝑡𝑥0ℝ(t,x)\in[0,\infty)\times\mathbb{R} and ω∈Ω𝜔Ω\omega\in\Omega, we will write uθε​(t,x,ω)superscriptsubscript𝑢𝜃𝜀𝑡𝑥𝜔u_{\theta}^{\varepsilon}(t,x,\omega) to denote ugε​(t,x,ω)superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑔𝜀𝑡𝑥𝜔u_{g}^{\varepsilon}(t,x,\omega) (see Lemma 5.1) when g​(x)=θ​x𝑔𝑥𝜃𝑥g(x)=\theta x. Note that

(5.4) uθε​(t,x,ω)=ε​uθ1​(t/ε,x/ε,ω)subscriptsuperscript𝑢𝜀𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔𝜀subscriptsuperscript𝑢1𝜃𝑡𝜀𝑥𝜀𝜔u^{\varepsilon}_{\theta}(t,x,\omega)=\varepsilon u^{1}_{\theta}(t/\varepsilon,x/\varepsilon,\omega)

by the uniqueness part of Lemma 5.1. With this notation, we define

(5.5) vθ​(t,x,ω)subscript𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔\displaystyle v_{\theta}(t,x,\omega) =euθ1​(t,x,ω)andabsentsuperscript𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝑢1𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔and\displaystyle=e^{u^{1}_{\theta}(t,x,\omega)}\quad\text{and}
v~θ​(t,x,ω)subscript~𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔\displaystyle\tilde{v}_{\theta}(t,x,\omega) =infα∈𝒫cEx​[eβ​∫0tV​(TXsα​ω)​𝑑s+θ​Xtα].absentsubscriptinfimum𝛼subscript𝒫𝑐subscript𝐸𝑥delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝛽superscriptsubscript0𝑡𝑉subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠𝛼𝜔differential-d𝑠𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝛼\displaystyle=\inf_{\alpha\in\mathcal{P}_{c}}E_{x}\left[e^{\beta\int_{0}^{t}V(T_{X_{s}^{\alpha}}\omega)ds+\theta X_{t}^{\alpha}}\right].
Lemma 5.3.

For every θ∈ℝ𝜃ℝ\theta\in\mathbb{R}, (t,x)∈[0,∞)×ℝ𝑡𝑥0ℝ(t,x)\in[0,\infty)\times\mathbb{R} and ω∈Ω𝜔Ω\omega\in\Omega,

(5.6) vθ​(t,x,ω)=v~θ​(t,x,ω).subscript𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔subscript~𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔v_{\theta}(t,x,\omega)=\tilde{v}_{\theta}(t,x,\omega).
Proof.

v~θ​(t,x,ω)subscript~𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔\tilde{v}_{\theta}(t,x,\omega) is the value function of a finite horizon, risk-sensitive stochastic optimal control problem with running payoff function x↦β​V​(Tx​ω)maps-to𝑥𝛽𝑉subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔x\mapsto\beta V(T_{x}\omega) and terminal payoff function x↦eθ​xmaps-to𝑥superscript𝑒𝜃𝑥x\mapsto e^{\theta x}. See [FS06, Chapter 6] for background. As we now show, v~θsubscript~𝑣𝜃\tilde{v}_{\theta} is a viscosity solution of the associated Bellman equation

(5.7) ∂v∂t𝑣𝑡\displaystyle\frac{\partial v}{\partial t} =12​∂2v∂x2+inf|a|≤c(a​∂v∂x)+β​V​(Tx​ω)​vabsent12superscript2𝑣superscript𝑥2subscriptinfimum𝑎𝑐𝑎𝑣𝑥𝛽𝑉subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔𝑣\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\frac{\partial^{2}v}{\partial x^{2}}+\inf_{|a|\leq c}\left(a\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}\right)+\beta V(T_{x}\omega)v

Lemma 5.4.

There exists a constant κ𝜅\kappa depending only on β𝛽\beta, c𝑐c, θ𝜃\theta and the Lipschitz constant of x↦V​(Tx​ω)maps-to𝑥𝑉subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔x\mapsto V(T_{x}\omega) such that

|log⁡v~θ​(s,x,ω)−log⁡v~θ​(t,y,ω)|≤κ​(|s−t|+|x−y|)subscript~𝑣𝜃𝑠𝑥𝜔subscript~𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑦𝜔𝜅𝑠𝑡𝑥𝑦|\log\tilde{v}_{\theta}(s,x,\omega)-\log\tilde{v}_{\theta}(t,y,\omega)|\leq\kappa(|s-t|+|x-y|)

for all s,t≥0𝑠𝑡0s,t\geq 0, x,y∈ℝ𝑥𝑦ℝx,y\in\mathbb{R} and ω∈Ω𝜔Ω\omega\in\Omega.

Proof.

Recall from the proof of Lemma 5.3 that log⁡v~θ​(t,x,ω)−θ​xsubscript~𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔𝜃𝑥\log\tilde{v}_{\theta}(t,x,\omega)-\theta x is a viscosity solution of (5.9) and log⁡v~θ​(0,x,ω)−θ​x=0subscript~𝑣𝜃0𝑥𝜔𝜃𝑥0\log\tilde{v}_{\theta}(0,x,\omega)-\theta x=0. It follows from [Dav16, Theorem 3.2] that log⁡v~θ​(t,x,ω)−θ​xsubscript~𝑣𝜃𝑡𝑥𝜔𝜃𝑥\log\tilde{v}_{\theta}(t,x,\omega)-\theta x is Lipschitz continuous in t∈[0,∞)𝑡0t\in[0,\infty) and x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R} with a Lipschitz constant κ′superscript𝜅′\kappa^{\prime} that depends only on β,c,θ𝛽𝑐𝜃\beta,c,\theta and the Lipschitz constant of x↦V​(Tx​ω)maps-to𝑥𝑉subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔x\mapsto V(T_{x}\omega) (which is finite by (1.4)). This implies the desired result. ∎

Remark 5.5.

If x↦V​(Tx​ω)maps-to𝑥𝑉subscript𝑇𝑥𝜔x\mapsto V(T_{x}\omega) is in Cb2​(ℝ)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑏2ℝC_{b}^{2}(\mathbb{R}), then uθεsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝜃𝜀u_{\theta}^{\varepsilon} is in fact a classical solution of the Cauchy problem (1.1)-(1.2) with g​(x)=θ​x𝑔𝑥𝜃𝑥g(x)=\theta x. See [FS06, Chapter 6, Remark 8.1].

Thus, by the implicit function theorem, the function θ↦Λβ​(θ)maps-to𝜃subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃\theta\mapsto\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta) is continuously differentiable on the set {θ∈ℝ:θ>0​and​Λβ​(θ)>β}conditional-set𝜃ℝ𝜃0andsubscriptΛ𝛽𝜃𝛽\{\theta\in\mathbb{R}:\,\theta>0\ \text{and}\ \Lambda_{\beta}(\theta)>\beta\}. Since Λβ​(−θ)=Λβ​(θ)subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃subscriptΛ𝛽𝜃\Lambda_{\beta}(-\theta)=\Lambda_{\beta}(\theta) and Λβ​(0)=βsubscriptΛ𝛽0𝛽\Lambda_{\beta}(0)=\beta by parts (a) and (c), this concludes the proof.∎
